hook.text: A woman sees spiders crawling across her ceiling every night as she falls asleep. She knows they aren't real.

buildup.text: Sleep-related hallucinations can be visual, auditory, or tactile. They occur at sleep onset or upon waking.

discovery.text: They result from dream imagery intruding into waking consciousness during the transition between states.

twist.text: Unlike psychotic hallucinations, sleep hallucinations are recognized as unreal by the person experiencing them.

climax.text: They affect up to 37 percent of people at some point, usually during periods of stress or sleep deprivation.

punchline.text: Seeing things at bedtime is more common than you think.

quiz.question: How do sleep-related hallucinations differ from psychotic ones?
options: The person recognizes them as unreal
They occur only during deep sleep
